title: A company is trying to collect on a Providian Card from 2001 that I never had that they say is $5,245.34 due. Is it a scam?
question: I filed for bankruptcy In 7/3/97 following my divorce and had everything discharged on 10/22/97, and never applied for any credit cards after that. It seems strange that a company, Malcolm S. Gerald and Associates, Inc. would try and collect money from someone 14 years later especially since they say they will gladly take $1,311.34 from me and go away. Is this a scam? Are they just trying to scare me into giving them money?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy court,Automatic stays in bankruptcy,Bankruptcy documents,Credit,Debt,Creditor harassment,Consumer debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal charges for harassment
answers:
If you do not want to take any action against them you might start off writing them a validation letter. That will require them to provide you with the details of the alleged debt so that you can evaluate it further.

If you are absolutely certain they can't be trying to collect a valid debt, you could send them a FOAD letter. It's an acronym for something impolite.

What's also possible is that there might be a lurking judgment. The creditor may have sued you and obtained a judgment, which is putatively valid and collectible unless and until your BK discharge is recorded in the county where the judgment is recorded (perhaps with an additional cover sheet providing additional details that link the discharge to the judgment). If this step is needed, you do not want to omit it.

You could check the county's records yourself, or you could pull your own Lexis/Nexis report to find out whether there is a situation you need to deal with.

Are you saying you never had any debt with Providian? If so, the contact may indeed be shady.

I will reposition this for you to get responses from the debt defense bar.

Maybe. This may/not be a scam.. Not enough information to opine further.
Debt may/not be enforceable. Depends on when incurred. Observations:
If debt incurred prior to BK file date it is discharged. You do not owe the money. Possible exceptions if bad faith failure to list debt on BK petition and schedules, an exception to discharge. Attempt to collect debt is violation of permanent stay. Creditor can be sanctioned.
If debt incurred after BK filed it is not discharged in BK.
Remember 10 year SOL on debts. Can be renewed.

If the debt predates your bankruptcy petition, consult your bankruptcy attorney to prosecute in Bankruptcy Court the violation of the automatic stay and discharge order. If the debt did not exist at the time that you filed bankruptcy, then you need to find out if there is a judgment against you and get the particulars, to meet with a consumer debt collection DEFENSE attorney to figure out your best course of action and options. If no judgment, and you have not made any payments in years on this account, then it is harassment in violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, if they have threatened you in any way with a lawsuit or collection of wages or levying bank accounts. Consult a consumer attorney about collection harassment within the one year statute of limitations, if you want to pursue that claim.
